summary: This is a letter from the law firm Smith Villazor LLP to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The firm, representing the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, informs the court that they have learned of a subpoena directed at the program and requests a briefing schedule to file a motion to quash it. The letter includes procedural deadlines set by the court.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the Southern District of New York handling the United States v. Maxwell case. The letter is addressed to her to request a briefing schedule regarding a subpoena.

persons.name: Patrick J. Smith
persons.context: Attorney from Smith Villazor LLP who signed the letter. He represents the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program and is requesting a schedule to file a motion to quash a subpoena.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Maxwell (No. 20 Cr. 330). The letter is part of the proceedings in her case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and accused sex trafficker. The letter mentions the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program was established to resolve claims of sexual abuse against him and his estate.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter via email, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter via email, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter via email, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Mark Stewart Cohen
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter via email, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter via email, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

connections.description: Patrick J. Smith's firm represents the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, as stated in the letter.
The document references the Maxwell criminal case and the program for claims against Epstein, implying their legal and alleged operational connection.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the United States v. Maxwell criminal case, as indicated by the case number and the letter's subject.

events.title: Letter to Judge Nathan Regarding Subpoena
events.description: Smith Villazor LLP informs Judge Nathan that the defendant (Maxwell) has sought a subpoena directed at the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program and requests a briefing schedule to file a motion to quash.

events.title: Government's Motion to Quash Deadline
events.description: The government's motion to quash the subpoena is due, as understood by the letter's authors.

events.title: Motion to Quash Filing Deadline
events.description: The court ordered that Patrick J. Smith may file a motion to quash the subpoena on or before this date.

events.title: Defense Response Deadline
events.description: The defense shall respond to both the government's and the program's motions to quash by this date.

locations.context: Address for the United States District Court, Southern District of New York, where Judge Nathan is located.
Law firm representing the administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

keyFacts: The Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, a litigation-alternative program to confidentially resolve sexual abuse claims against Jeffrey Epstein and his estate, is represented by the law firm Smith Villazor LLP.

In the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, the defense sought a subpoena directed at the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, prompting the program's attorneys to request a schedule to file a motion to quash it.
The government also intended to file a motion to quash the same subpoena, indicating both the prosecution and the victims' program had concerns about the defense's subpoena.
The document reveals ongoing legal maneuvering in the Maxwell case shortly before trial, with the victims' compensation program becoming a target of discovery requests.
Judge Alison J. Nathan set specific deadlines for motions to quash and responses, showing active court management of pre-trial subpoena disputes.
